newsitem.title: USA: RESEARCH ALERT-DMG sees solid U.S. corp. PC demand.
newsitem.headline: RESEARCH ALERT-DMG sees solid U.S. corp. PC demand.

text.p: -- DMG Technology Group says in a research note that despite fears to the contrary, industry data shows U.S. corporate demand for personal computers and information technology "remains solid."
-- DMG Technology Group forecasts 1997 worldwide PC Unit shipment growth of 16 percent, down from 18 percent in 1996.
-- Revenue growth in 1997 seen at 17 percent, with average selling prices expected to track upwards this year.
-- Analysts keep in place six-month long prediction that overall U.S. and U.S. corporate PC demand will grow by 15 percent in 1997.
-- Analysts say in note they "believe that Intel demand continues to be strong and that it has sold out some high end products."
-- Research group says checks with distribution channel indicate solid January growth, with following year-over-year projections for the first month of 1997:
-- Sees Inacom Corp sales up 40 percent.
-- Sees Ingram Micro saels up 20 percent.
-- Sees CompuCom sales up 15-20 percent in January "after a slow start."
-- Sees MicroAge Inc sales up 15-20 percent "after a slow start."
-- Sees Tech Data Corp up 45 percent "somewhat above company expectations."
-- Says Vanstar "indicated sales were up 20 percent year on year and said the first nine days of Bebruary are trackinng similarly."
-- Says direct PC channel "appears to be tracking well into the new year, with major vendors up an average 35 percent.

-- Forecasts Dell Computer revenue rose 42 percent to $2.2 billion, equalling average growth rate for the first three quarters of fiscal 1997. Notes that Dell reports results after the market on Tuesday, February 25.

-- Says Gateway 2000 "indicated record call volumes in January, but experienced a slight pause in close rates early in the month as customers were assessing MMX. Close rates acceperated later in the month..." Says company is "on track" to meet or beat DMG's Q1 revenue projection of $1.5 billion, up 29 percent.
-- Groups says despite 3Coms comments Monday which rattled its stock and the networking sector, DMG believes demand for data networking equipment "appears to be strong."

-- Sees 3Com events as short-term anomalies unrelated to its longer-term prospects or industry demand. Notes softness in 3Com stackable hubs due to competition from Bay Networks and market shift to low-end switches and also notes 3Com had excessive channel inventory that had to be reduced in December, with levels now at desired 4-6 weeks. Says drop by 35 percent in Fast Ethernet adapter cards, following Intel, part of trend which could accelerate shift to Fast Ethernet.
-- Inacom Corp shares rose 2-1/2 to 29-1/4.
-- Ingram Micro stock rose 7/8 to 21-7/8.
-- CompuCom shares off 3/8 at 8-1/2.
-- MicroAge Inc gained 1-1/4 to 13-3/4
-- Tech Data Corp rose 3/8 to 25.
-- Vanstar fell 1/2 to 13-7/8.
-- Dell Computer shares rose 3-1/16 to 66-11/16.
-- Gateway 2000 rose 1-5/8 to 61.
-- 3Com Corp rose 2-1/2 to 40.
-- Bay Networks rose 7/8 to 19-3/4.
-- Reuters Palo Alto Bureau +1 415 846 5400
